title: The Virus Years: A U.S. Covid Retrospective
content:
Although its worst impacts have been unevenly distributed, the Covid-19 pandemic has indelibly touched every corner of American life. We present a survey in word, image, and data.

BY JANE ROBERTS AND ALEXANDER KENNEDY
04.18.2021

Nearly two and a half years since a mysterious cluster of pneumonia cases was first reported in Wuhan, China, SARS-CoV-2 has killed more than 6 million people and sickened hundreds of millions more around the world. In that time, many governments — from the local to national level — have gone to extraordinary lengths to combat the spread of the deadly pathogen, from closing borders and implementing contact tracing systems to adopting mask mandates and shutting down businesses. Others — including at times the United States — have downplayed the severity of the virus and touted unproven treatments against it.

As health care workers burned out, the development of vaccines brought new hope. But even with billions of shots now in arms, much of the world’s population has yet to receive a single dose. While many people living in low-income countries simply still lack access, pockets of Americans and others have chosen to willfully forgo the vaccine — and push back on efforts to mandate it. Following the rise of a Covid virus variant that would be named delta by the World Health Organization, a more worrying variant, called omicron, swept the globe and inundated hospitals.

While cases declined in many parts of the globe following records in January of this year, an omicron subvariant led to new spikes, including in Hong Kong and the U.K. With the pandemic now in its third year, scientists are scrambling to determine where things are headed next. But what may already be clear, many experts say, is that the coronavirus is likely to become endemic — meaning rather than disappearing, it will become less disruptive as the population builds immunity over time.

The Pandemic, Day by Day

What follows is a timeline of key moments in more than two years of the pandemic. As you scroll through these events, states on the accompanying map will populate when they experienced their first Covid-19 cases. The map will continually update to indicate both per capita and total cases over time.

We will periodically update the timeline and data until Covid-19 is declared endemic.

Visual: Lerone Pieters/Unsplash

headline: The First U.S. Cases
content:
2020  |  On Jan. 21, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirms the United States' first case of the novel coronavirus, in a man in Washington State. In the coming days, sporadic cases would surface in other states — Illinois, California, Arizona, Massachusetts — and an increasing number of airports began screening arriving passengers for the virus. Continue scrolling to read more. States will appear on the map to the right as their first cases arise.
 
Below, John Wiesman, then-secretary of health for Washington State, takes questions as news of the case emerges.
 

Visual: Jason Redmond/AFP via Getty Images
 
A NOTE ON NAVIGATION
You will periodically encounter the navigation menu below. Use it to skip ahead or back to the beginning of each year.
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: A Public Health Crisis
content: U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar declares the coronavirus a public health emergency on Jan. 31, just one day after the World Health Organization does the same. President Donald J. Trump issued a proclamation barring foreign nationals — excluding immediate family members of U.S. citizens and permanent residents — from entering the country if they had visited China in the previous two weeks.

headline: A Whistleblower Dies
content:
On Feb. 7, Dr. Li Wenliang, a Chinese ophthalmologist who tried to warn others about the developing outbreak in Wuhan, dies after contracting the virus himself. In December, Li sounded an alarm to fellow doctors in a chat room, but was accused of making false statements and quickly silenced by authorities. Mourners across the U.S., and the world, paid their respects, including outside the UCLA campus in California (below).
 

Visual: Mark Ralston / AFP via Getty

headline: Cruise Ship Quarantine
content:
After days of quarantine offshore, the Diamond Princess cruise ship docks at Yokohama port near Tokyo, and beginning on Feb. 17, hundreds of American passengers are evacuated and flown to California and Texas. At least 14 evacuees tested positive for the coronavirus — which the World Health Organization dubbed Covid-19 — and all were subject to a two-week quarantine upon their return to the U.S.
 

Visual: Kazuhiro Nogi/AFP via Getty Images
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Nursing Homes Impacted
content:
Covid-19 spreads among staff and residents at a nursing home in Kirkland, Washington. The facility would go on to be linked to dozens of deaths and face a $611,000 fine for deficiencies that led to the country’s first major coronavirus outbreak. With many older residents living in close quarters, nursing homes are particularly vulnerable to the virus. Below, Cynthia Tachner, 86, waits to visit through glass with her daughter at a nursing home in California.
 

Visual: Sarah Reingewirtz/Los Angeles Daily News via Getty

headline: Pandemic Declaration
content: On March 11, the World Health Organization declares Covid-19 a pandemic, as global cases rise above 118,000 and deaths top 4,000. In a media briefing, WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus advised countries that with measures to “test, treat, isolate, trace, and mobilize their people in the response,” it’s would still be possible to “change the course of this pandemic.”

headline: Stay at Home
content:
On March 19, California becomes the first state to issue a stay-at-home order for residents, directing them to leave only for exercise and other essential purposes. Many other states soon followed, with officials banning indoor dining and prohibiting large gatherings, among other measures. Many companies shut down their offices and asked employees to work from home until further notice.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

A highway sign in Los Angeles advises residents to stay home to prevent the spread of Covid-19.
 
Visual: Aydin Palabiyikoglu/Getty

headline: The Rise of Face Masks ...
content: In early April, after weeks of discouraging the use of masks among the general public — in part to ensure supplies remained available to medical professionals — U.S. health officials begin encouraging Americans to wear cloth face coverings to help stop the spread of Covid-19. Instructions for fashioning homemade masks proliferated online, and community members came together to sew masks for those in need.

headline: ... and Mobile Morgues
content:
On April 7, New York City experiences its deadliest day of the Covid-19 pandemic so far; more than 800 residents passed away. With morgues and funeral homes overwhelmed, bodies were stored in refrigerated trucks provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, or FEMA.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

At Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island, members of the New York City chapter of the Laborers' Union International, Local 79, build shelving for trailers to hold the bodies of Covid-19 victims.
 
Visual: Pacific Press/Getty

headline: Beginnings in California
content:
Post-mortem testing of two people who died in Santa Clara County in February suggests that the coronavirus was circulating in California at least a month earlier than originally thought. According to the county medical examiner, a 57-year-old woman who died on Feb. 6 was the first known person to die from Covid-19 in the U.S., followed by a 69-year-old man, who died on Feb. 17.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

A respiratory specialist looks through the glass as a team at Boston Medical Center performs a tracheostomy on a Covid-19 patient on the intensive care unit floor of the hospital.
 
Visual: Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images

headline: A Spike in Illinois
content:
Illinois documents its largest single-day Covid-19 spike, with 4,014 new cases recorded in the 24 hours between May 11 and 12. The increase coincided with the state’s increase in testing. “We have not had [a number] in the 4,000 range before,” Ngozi Ezike, head of the Illinois Department of Public Health, told Block Club Chicago, “but we also have never had tests in the 29,000 range.” As deaths rose and thousands were hospitalized, Gov. J.B. Pritzker asked residents to continue following the state’s stay-at-home order.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

People spread out across social-distancing circles at Dolores Park in San Francisco.
 
Visual: Jane Tyska/Digital First Media/East Bay Times via Getty Images

headline: Racial Disparities
content: By late May of 2020, the U.S. emerges as the first country in the world to surpass 100,000 deaths from Covid-19, and demographic analyses expose the racial disparities of that toll. In Alabama, while only 27 percent of residents are Black, they accounted for 44 percent of Covid-19 deaths. In Michigan, African Americans make up 14 percent of the population but made up 40 percent of deaths in the state.

A couple exchanges vows as part of a virtual wedding ceremony in Morris Plains, New Jersey. Such ceremonies grew in popularity as in-person weddings were cancelled or drastically downsized due to the pandemic.
 
Visual: Theo Wargo/Getty Images

headline: Covid Lung Transplant
content:
On June 5, a Chicago woman in her 20s becomes the first known person in the U.S. to receive a double lung transplant for Covid-19. The woman, who was otherwise healthy, developed a severe case of the disease and spent two months in an intensive care unit. Her lungs were so damaged that doctors said a transplant was her only chance at survival.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: California Mask Mandate
content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom issues a statewide mask mandate on June 18. With coronavirus cases increasing, the Department of Public Health said, the order required people to wear face coverings in public spaces to “limit the release of infected droplets when talking, coughing, and/or sneezing, as well as reinforce physical distancing."

A young girl walks with her mother on Santee Alley in the Garment District in Downtown L.A., where masks were required for shopping.
 
Visual: Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images


GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022

headline: Aerosol Spread
content:
In the second week of July, the WHO revises its guidance on Covid-19 transmission, acknowledging that it’s possible the virus could be airborne in indoor spaces. The update came after hundreds of scientists around the world urged the agency to reevaluate its stance. While the WHO maintained that transmission occurred primarily through close contact with infected people, other experts argued that tiny droplets called aerosols might be behind superspreader events. An annual motorcycle rally in South Dakota the following month (below) became such an event in the summer of 2020.
 

Visual: Michael Ciaglo/Getty Images

headline: Florida's Record Deaths
content:
On July 23, Florida reported 173 new Covid-19 deaths — its highest toll so far. Earlier in the month, the state broke the record for the highest number of new cases in the U.S., reporting more than 15,000 on July 12. Of the 3.2 million tests Florida had administered since the pandemic began, 12.1 percent came back positive — well above the WHO recommendation of 5 percent. Despite the spike, Disney World reopened on July 11, after being shut down for four months.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

Jackson Pijanowski 9, (L) and Bright Owens, (R), supporters calling for Hillsborough County schools to reopen, protest ahead of a meeting of the school board at the Hillsborough County Public Schools district office on Aug. 6, 2020 in Tampa, Florida.
 
Visual: Octavio Jones/Getty Images

headline: Covid in Kids
content:
As Texas parents consider sending their children back to school in the fall, Covid-19 testing slows and, of the tests being administered, around one-fifth come back positive. While evidence suggested that children were less likely to experience severe illness than adults, they can and do spread the virus. Below, kids prepare to enter a Pennsylvania school in the fall of 2020.
 

Visual: Ben Hasty/Reading Eagle via Getty

headline: College Outbreak
content:
By the end of August, more than 1,200 students and 166 employees test positive for Covid-19 at the University of Alabama, after the school reopened for in-person instruction earlier in the month. Other institutions, including the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Michigan State, also experienced outbreaks, with both schools shifting to remote learning.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: AstraZeneca Concerns
content: In early September, AstraZeneca pauses a large study on its Covid-19 vaccine after a patient in the United Kingdom experienced a suspected serious adverse reaction. A spokesperson told STAT that the company initiated the hold on the Phase 3 trial, which was being conducted at sites across the U.S., “to allow review of safety data.”

headline: School Covid Dashboards
content:
Texas launches an online dashboard to track coronavirus cases in public schools. As of Sept. 17, 2020 the dashboard showed 4,519 positive cases, divided fairly equally between students and staff. In addition to reporting cases to the state, schools were still required to notify local health authorities.
 

Visual: KHOU

headline: Trump Tests Positive
content:
President Donald J. Trump and First Lady Melania Trump announce on Oct. 2 that they have tested positive for Covid-19. On Sept. 26, the president hosted an event at the White House Rose Garden (below) to announce Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s appointment to the Supreme Court. Several attendees also tested positive, as did many of Trump’s other close contacts.
 

Visual: Jabin Botsford/Washington Post via Getty
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

President Trump exits the White House to head to a rally in Pennsylvania after recovering from Covid-19 earlier in the month.
 
Visual: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images

headline: Voting in a Pandemic
content:
As the Nov. 3 presidential election approaches, public health officials weigh in on how to stay safe while voting in a pandemic. For those who hadn't already submitted their votes by mail or local dropbox, health authorities said common sense precautions like mask wearing, social distancing, and sanitizing pens between voters should help.
 
For the next several months, attempts by the Trump administration and its supporters to overturn the election victory of President Joseph R. Biden would overshadow Covid's continued spread.
 

Visual: Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty

headline: Illinois Cases Surge
content:
On Nov. 16 and Nov. 17, Illinois records its highest average daily case toll since the start of the pandemic. On those days, the state averaged almost 12,400 new cases a day, with Nov. 17 marking the 12th day in a row with more than 10,000 new cases tallied. Gov. J.B. Pritzker announced new restrictions to combat the spread.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

Ignoring CDC guidance not to travel for the Thanksgiving holiday to prevent the spread of the virus, travelers waited in line at a TSA checkpoint at Orlando International Airport.
 
Visual: Paul Hennessy/NurPhoto via Getty Images

headline: First Vaccine Authorized
content:
On Dec. 11, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration grants an emergency use authorization for the first vaccine against Covid-19. The shot, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, would first be made available to nursing home residents and health care workers. Pfizer was set to supply 100 million doses to the U.S. government by March.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Moderna Quickly Follows
content: The FDA issues an emergency use authorization for Moderna's vaccine on Dec. 18, approving the federal government’s plan to distribute some 5.9 million doses the following week. “We likely will see shots in the arm by the very early part of next week, I would hope Monday or Tuesday,” Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told the Today show on Dec. 18.

headline: Deadly December
content: California experiences its deadliest month yet in the pandemic, reporting more than 5,300 deaths related to the virus in December. The state's previous record came in August with some 3,800 fatalities. While the number of new cases was beginning to stabilize, the state still faced surges in deaths and hospitalizations, as well as limited or no availability in its ICUs. Meanwhile, a new and more worrying variant of the virus was beginning to circulate in India.

A health care worker exits the Covid-19 intensive care unit on New Year's Day at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston, Texas.
 
Visual: Go Nakamura/Getty Images

GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022

headline: Texas Hospitalizations Spike
content:
2021  |  Texas reports more than 14,000 Covid-19 hospitalizations in mid-January, its highest number since the pandemic began. According to the state’s health department, Thanksgiving and Christmas get togethers helped to drive the rise in cases. Due to the influx of patients, the availability of intensive care unit beds was extremely limited.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: New President, New Variants
content:
Researchers identify two new variants of the coronavirus in Columbus, Ohio. Their findings, which had not yet been peer reviewed at this time, suggested that at least one of the variants contained the same mutation found in variants from the U.K. and South Africa. Scientists said the emergence of variants wasn’t itself a cause for concern. What was important was whether they turned out to be more contagious or led to more severe disease.
 
Later in the month, newly elected President Joe Biden would be sworn into office, extolling Americans to "set aside the politics and finally face this pandemic as one nation."

People wait outside a Covid-19 vaccine distribution center at the Kedren Community Health Center in L.A.
 
Visual: Mario Tama/Getty Images

headline: U.K. Variant Warning
content:
Public health officials begin warning Americans that the coronavirus variant first identified in the United Kingdom could become the dominant strain in the U.S. in the coming months — leading to a spike in cases. While it was not yet clear if the variant would cause more deaths or severe disease, the CDC urged people to remain vigilant in their pandemic precautions.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: J&J Jab Authorized
content: In late February, the FDA approves the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine under an emergency use authorization. With three options now available, more Americans would be able to get their Covid-19 shots. But because Johnson & Johnson had a lower efficacy than Pfizer and Moderna, public health officials worried that some people could be reluctant to get it.

headline: Spikes Across the Country
content:
Although millions of people are getting vaccinated every day, and caseloads are down across the United States, counts in some pockets of the country start rising again in March. According to The Washington Post, Michigan’s daily number of infections increased, as did tallies in Minnesota and Maryland. Below, nurses in Virgina prepare to administer vaccines.
 

Visual: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: One Year In
content: Just over a year into the pandemic, the CDC releases data showing that Covid-19 was the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. in 2020. Of the approximately 375,000 deaths attributed to the disease caused by the virus, people of color were hit the hardest.

headline: Colleges Split on Vaccines
content:
By April, some U.S. colleges are indicating that they will require students to get vaccinated before returning to campus in the fall, while others will leave the decision up to individuals. Some schools, including Virginia Tech, did not believe they could legally mandate vaccines that had only received emergency use authorization from the FDA. But legal scholars suggested the larger issue would come from states pushing back on such requirements.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Mask Guidelines Eased
content:
As spring gets underway and vaccines roll out, the CDC eases mask guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals. Those who had received a two-dose regimen of the Pfizer or Moderna shots, or a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, could forgo masks when doing outdoor activities or meeting with friends for outdoor dining. The agency still recommended masking indoors, regardless of vaccination status. Below, New York City nightlife resumes in earnest.
 

Visual: Alexi Rosenfeld/Getty Images

headline: One Step Further
content:
The agency relaxes its guidelines further, giving fully vaccinated individuals the go ahead to ditch their masks and forgo social distancing indoors. While masks were still required on planes and public transportation, in updating the guidance, the CDC cited three studies supporting the efficacy of the vaccines.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: CDC on Breakthrough Cases
content:
Following widely publicized reports of Covid-19 infection in fully vaccinated people, a new CDC report suggests that such breakthrough cases are extremely rare. Of the 101 million U.S. adults who had been fully vaccinated by the end of April, the report said, just .01 percent — or about 10,260 — got Covid-19.
 
Meanwhile, in coming days and weeks, Americans would learn of the delta variant, which would quickly become the dominant Covid-19 strain across the globe.

People take to the beach in Coney Island to enjoy some fresh air after months of Covid-19 restrictions. By this point, nearly 60 percent of adult New Yorkers had been fully vaccinated against the virus.
 
Visual: Mathias Wasik/picture alliance via Getty Images

GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022

headline: Deaths Top 600,000
content: By mid-June 2021, more than 600,000 people have died from Covid-19 in the United States, more than any other country thus far. Still, public health experts pointed out, the numbers had ticked up much more slowly since vaccines became available.

headline: Crisis of the Unvaccinated
content:
By June, reports suggest that most of the people dying from Covid-19 in the U.S. are unvaccinated. Of the more than 18,000 people who died of the illness in May 2021, only 150, or less than 1 percent, were fully vaccinated. More than a third of those eligible still had yet to receive their first dose of a Covid vaccine.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Missouri Surge
content: Covid-19 cases rise rapidly in Missouri, increasing 46 percent in late June ane early July. As ABC News reported, the CDC assigned two members of its federal "surge team" to the state — an epidemiologist to work on "genetic sequencing and data analysis, and an adviser who's working with local officials on how to address vaccine hesitancy."

Tens of thousands of fans gather outside of Fiserv Forum to celebrate the Milwaukee Bucks 2021 NBA Championship win. With much of Wisconsin's population still unvaccinated at this point, health experts said they expected to see new Covid cases tied to the event.
 
Visual: Jamie Sabau/Getty Images


 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: The Show Goes On
content:
An estimated 100,000 people gather at Chicago’s Grant Park on July 29 for the kickoff of the city’s Lollapalooza music festival. For some, the event — which required attendees to show their vaccination card or a recent negative Covid test — signaled optimism about the return of live events. But others cautioned that as the delta variant spread, many attendees could contract Covid.
 

Visual: Armando L. Sanchez/Chicago Tribune via Getty Images

headline: Breakthrough Transmission
content:
In August, CDC director Rochelle Walensky announces that people who get Covid-19 even after being fully vaccinated could still transmit the virus to others. The revelation prompted the public health agency to revise its guidance once again, recommending that fully vaccinated people continue to wear masks indoors. "Our vaccines are working exceptionally well," Walensky told CNN. "They continue to work well for delta, with regard to severe illness and death — they prevent it. But what they can't do anymore is prevent transmission."
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Struggles in the South
content: States across the southern U.S. experience another surge in Covid-19 cases in late summer. In Mississippi, health officials warned that "the state's hospital system could collapse in five to 10 days if the current trajectory continues." Meanwhile, Arkansas experienced record hospitalizations and 90 percent of ICU beds in Florida were full.

headline: Booster Shots
content:
As U.S. public health officials warn of potentially waning immunity against the coronavirus in the coming months, booster shots of both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are set to become available to American adults in September. While people who received the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine would also likely need an additional shot, research was still ongoing.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

A boy rides a bicycle past a sign at Pershing School in Orlando advising that face masks are required for students through Oct. 30, 2021. On Aug. 27, a Florida judge threw out Gov. Ron DeSantis' ban on face mask mandates in schools.
 
Visual: Paul Hennessy/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

headline: Federal Vaccine Mandates
content:
On Sept. 9, President Biden announces that all federal workers and contractors will be required to get vaccinated against Covid-19. In addition, companies with 100 employees or more will have to ensure workers were vaccinated or have them undergo weekly testing. "The bottom line — we're going to protect vaccinated workers from unvaccinated coworkers," Biden said.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Rules Relax in Florida
content: On Sept. 22, Florida's new surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, issues an executive order to make quarantine optional for students exposed to Covid-19. While Gov. Ron DeSantis stated that the order was aimed at preventing healthy students from unnecessarily missing school, many public health officials warned that it could fuel asymptomatic transmission.

headline: 700,000 Covid-19 Deaths
content: The U.S. hits a grim pandemic milestone on Oct. 1, as the nation's Covid-19 death toll surpassed 700,000. While vaccines were available to all Americans 12 and older, tens of millions continued to hold out, allowing the more contagious delta variant to spread.

headline: Spikes in the Heartland
content: In Douglas County, Nebraska — the state's most populous — the health department reports 190 new Covid-19 cases on Oct. 8. That brings the county total to more than 84,500 cases since the pandemic began. On Oct. 7, the health department said 89 percent of hospital beds were taken and ICUs were 87 percent full.

headline: Colin Powell Dies From Covid
content:
On Oct. 18, former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell dies after a battle with Covid-19. Powell, who held the post under President George W. Bush, was fully vaccinated but had a compromised immune system due to treatment he was receiving for blood cancer.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Pfizer Authorized for Kids
content: On Nov. 2, the CDC recommends Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11, expanding eligibility to tens of millions of Americans. While many parents welcomed the news, others — including those who are vaccinated themselves — expressed hesitation about consenting for their kids.

Thousands take to the California State Capitol steps in Sacramento to protest the Covid-19 vaccine mandate for students.
 
Visual: Anibal Martel/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

headline: Alarm Over Omicron Variant
content:
The WHO warns that the omicron variant, which first appeared in South Africa earlier in November, is very likely to spread globally. “Given mutations that may confer immune escape potential and possibly transmissibility advantage, the likelihood of potential further spread of omicron at the global level is high,” the agency said in a technical brief. Though data was limited at this time, symptoms with the new variant were reported to be fairly mild.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Covid-19 Holiday Surge
content: With Christmas and New Year's fast approaching, cases of Covid-19 surge in New York City. In a tweet, Dr. Jay Varma, a health adviser to then-Mayor Bill de Blasio, wrote that from Dec. 9 to Dec. 12, the city's test positivity rate went from 3.9 percent to 7.8 percent. With a reporting lag of a few days, however, the true rate could have actually been higher.

headline: Virus Grounds Flights
content:
Covid-19 upends holiday plans once again, as staffing issues caused hundreds of flight cancellations on Christmas Day. Delta, United, and Alaska, among other airlines, said employees infected with and exposed to the omicron variant left them without the staffing necessary to operate.
 

Visual: RJ Sangosti/The Denver Post via Getty

headline: Single Day Case Record
content:
2022  |  On Jan. 10, the U.S. records 1.35 million new Covid-19 infections, the largest single-day total of any country in the world since the start of the pandemic. The record was accompanied by the highest number of patients hospitalized with Covid-19, reaching more than 136,000.
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: U.S. Drops Vaccine Rule
content: At the end of January, the U.S. Department of Labor drops a vaccine mandate for businesses with more than 100 employees, after it was blocked by the Supreme Court. The rule had been aimed at increasing vaccine uptake, but faced strong pushback from conservative groups.

headline: Vaccine for Kids Delayed
content: In mid-February, the FDA delays a decision over whether to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for the nation’s youngest children for at least another two months. While the agency had originally planned to make a call by the following week, Pfizer and BioNTech submitted new data that will require additional review. While parents await the authorization, the agency noted the best way to protect kids is to continue following masking and social distancing guidelines.

headline: Masks Come Off
content:
In new guidelines issued in late February, the CDC advises that many Americans can once again forgo masks and social distancing. To assess a community’s risk, the recommendations direct counties to look at a handful of factors, including new Covid-19 cases per 100,000 people and hospital admissions. The agency suggests a tiered approach to masking based on local conditions and individuals' personal health risks.
 

Visual: Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune via Getty
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END

headline: Living with Covid
content: As the second anniversary of the Covid-19 pandemic approaches, public health experts weigh in on a path to the “next normal.” In a 136-page report, the authors — who include Paul Offit, director of the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia’s Vaccine Education Center, and Jill Jim, executive director of the Navajo Department of Health — suggested the U.S. shift its Covid-19 response to include other respiratory viruses and improve indoor air quality, among other initiatives.

headline: A Fresh Warning
content:
Although Covid-19 cases continue to decline, top White House coronavirus adviser Anthony Fauci warns Americans to remain vigilant. In the U.K., where restrictions are being lifted and protection from vaccines is waning, cases rose again due to an omicron subvariant called BA.2. With the U.S. often following a similar pattern to the U.K., Fauci said new funding for additional vaccine doses and therapeutic treatments is sorely need.
 

Visual: Greg Nash/AFP via Getty

headline: County Level Risks
content: New reported cases trend downward in Kentucky, but nearly a dozen counties were still catergorized as high by the CDC in late March, meaning residents were advised to mask indoors while in public and take additional precautions if they were at an elevated risk for severe disease, among other measures.

headline: Detecting the Next Surge
content: Health experts warn that as testing decreases, the U.S. could face difficulties in detecting the next wave of Covid-19. Restrictions have loosened across the country, and many Americans are eager to leave the pandemic behind. But as Gregg Gonsalves, an infectious disease expert at Yale, told Bloomberg: " These late waves of the pandemics are sometimes the deadliest because people have given up.”

headline: Mask Mandate Falls
content:
In a 59-page ruliing issued April 18, a federal judge in Florida strikes down the years-long federal mandate requiring masks on public transportation, including airlines and in airports. Arguing that the requirement, repeatedly renewed by the Biden administration, exceeded federal public health authority, the judge effectively ended one of the most enduring emblems of the pandemic — and reports of spontaneous, in-air, mask-stripping celebrations, as news reached passengers and crew aboard active flights, were shared widely on social media. Below, a couple poses maskless upon arriving at LAX.
 

Visual: Brittany Murray/Long Beach Press-Telegram via Getty
 
GO TO: 2020 | 2021 | 2022 | TOP | END
